explanation:
- struct MHD_Daemon (complete definition): The function casts the void *cls to struct MHD_Daemon * and reads/writes several members (tid, sigpipe_blocked, shutdown, options). You must see the structure definition to know which members are modified here and whether any members are const-qualified.
- MHD_thread_handle_ID_set_current_thread_ID_ (prototype): Called with &(daemon->tid). Its prototype shows whether it expects a pointer to mutable tid storage (i.e. will modify the object). If it modifies tid, daemon cannot be treated as pointing to const.
- MHD_poll (prototype): Called with daemon. The prototype reveals whether it accepts struct MHD_Daemon * or const struct MHD_Daemon * and whether it may modify daemon state.
- MHD_epoll (prototype): Same reason as MHD_poll — need to know parameter constness and whether the function mutates the daemon.
- MHD_select (prototype): Same rationale — its signature/behavior determines whether daemon is mutated by the call.
- MHD_cleanup_connections (prototype): Called after polling; must know if it mutates daemon or its internals (and therefore whether the daemon pointer must be non-const).
- resume_suspended_connections (prototype): Called both in-loop and on shutdown; prototype determines whether it mutates daemon or relies on non-const access.
- close_all_connections (prototype): Called on shutdown and clearly likely mutates daemon/its connections; need its prototype to confirm non-const usage requirement.
- MHD_DLOG (prototype): Logging is called with daemon in some branches; prototype may take a non-const daemon pointer or const — need to know if it modifies daemon or requires non-const.
- MHD_D_IS_USING_POLL_ (macro/inline definition): Used to select polling method; its definition may dereference daemon and indicate whether it takes/assumes mutable or const access.
- MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_ (macro/inline definition): Same as above for epoll selection.
- MHD_TEST_ALLOW_SUSPEND_RESUME (macro/constant): Used with daemon->options to decide calling resume_suspended_connections; include to ensure understanding of options field and whether checking it implies any modification.

In short: to judge whether cls/daemon could be declared as a pointer-to-const (or must be non-const) you must examine the daemon type (which members are written here) and the signatures/semantics of every callee that takes daemon (or its members) to see whether they perform modifications. The listed symbols are the minimal definitions/prototypes/macros needed to make that determination.
